speaker: Doctor
text: What is the age of the newborn, and when did the feeding intolerance and bilious vomiting start?

speaker: Patient
text: I am a newborn, just six hours old. The feeding intolerance and bilious vomiting started within the first day after birth.

speaker: Doctor
text: Has the newborn had any bowel movements since birth, and if so, what was the appearance of the stool?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any bowel movements since birth.

speaker: Doctor
text: Has the newborn been able to tolerate any fluids or feedings at all, or has there been complete intolerance?

speaker: Patient
text: I have not been able to tolerate any fluids or feedings at all.

speaker: Doctor
text: Has the newborn shown any signs of abdominal distension or tenderness upon examination?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't been examined for abdominal distension or tenderness yet, but I feel uncomfortable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any signs of bile in the vomit, such as a greenish color?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, the vomit has a greenish color, which I believe indicates bile.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any signs of respiratory distress or abnormal breathing patterns in the newborn?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't shown any signs of respiratory distress, and my breathing seems normal.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any maternal complications during pregnancy or delivery that we should be aware of?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't have any information about maternal complications, but I know my mother missed several prenatal checkups.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any signs of abdominal swelling or any visible loops of bowel upon physical examination?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't been examined for abdominal swelling or visible loops of bowel yet, but I feel some discomfort in my belly.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in the newborn's skin color, such as jaundice or pallor?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any changes in my skin color, so I don't think I have jaundice or pallor.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any signs of meconium passage, or has there been any indication of a meconium ileus?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't passed any meconium since birth, so I don't think there's been any indication of a meconium ileus.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any signs of dehydration, such as dry mucous membranes or decreased skin turgor?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't been examined for dehydration, but I feel a bit dry and uncomfortable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any episodes of lethargy or decreased responsiveness since birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't experienced any episodes of lethargy or decreased responsiveness, but I do feel a bit uncomfortable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any family history of gastrointestinal issues or congenital abnormalities?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, my older brother had surgery for pyloric stenosis when he was an infant.

speaker: Doctor
text: Given your brother's history of pyloric stenosis, I need to ask if there have been any signs of projectile vomiting or if the vomiting has been forceful?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, the vomiting has been quite forceful, almost like it comes out suddenly.

speaker: Doctor
text: Given the forceful vomiting and the absence of bowel movements, I need to assess for any potential obstruction. REQUEST TEST: Abdominal_Ultrasound.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Given the normal abdominal ultrasound results, I need to ask if there have been any signs of abdominal pain or discomfort that seem to come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any specific episodes of abdominal pain that come and go, but I do feel discomfort consistently.

speaker: Doctor
text: Given the consistent discomfort and the absence of bowel movements, I need to know if there have been any signs of a distended abdomen upon physical examination. Have you been examined for that yet?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't been examined for abdominal distension yet, but I do feel some discomfort in my belly.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any signs of a "currant jelly" stool, which can indicate a specific type of obstruction?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any bowel movements at all, so I haven't experienced any stool, including "currant jelly" stool.

speaker: Doctor
text: Given the symptoms of bilious vomiting, feeding intolerance, and the absence of bowel movements, I need to ask if there have been any signs of abdominal distension upon physical examination. Have you been examined for that yet?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't been examined for abdominal distension yet, but I do feel some discomfort in my belly.

speaker: Doctor
text: Given the symptoms you've described, including bilious vomiting, feeding intolerance, and the absence of bowel movements, I suspect a possible condition. I will proceed with my diagnosis. DIAGNOSIS READY: Duodenal Atresia
